title-group.article-title: Interlaminar/interfiber failure of unidirectional glass fiber reinforced composites used for wind turbine blades

article-meta.aff: 2Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Aalborg University, Aalborg, Denmark
3Robert McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, USA

author-notes.corresp: Martin Leong, Siemens Wind Power A/S, Assensvej 11, Aalborg, DK-9220, Denmark. Email: martin.leong@siemens.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A unidirectional glass fiber/epoxy composite was characterized under multi-axial loading by testing off-axis specimens under uniaxial tension and compression at various angles relative to the fiber direction. Iosipescu shear tests were performed with both symmetric and asymmetric specimens. Tests were performed on both 1-2 and 1-3 material coordinate planes. Strain gauges and Digital Image Correlation were used to record the stress–strain responses. A new approach was used to define a ‘failure initiation strength’ by analyzing the recorded stress–strain curves. The experimentally determined failure stresses were compared with the predictions of the maximum stress, Tsai-Wu and Northwestern University failure criteria. It was found that using the approach of analyzing the stress–strain curve to define a point of material failure initiation, it was possible to obtain good correlation between the experimental data and predictions by both the Tsai-Wu and the NU failure criteria.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The design and analysis of thick laminated composite structures require a thorough understanding of the behavior of the basic materials when they are subjected to various states of stress. Although fiber-reinforced materials should be designed to carry the primary loads in the longitudinal fiber direction, multi-axial stress states are often induced in and near structural joints, load introduction areas, zones near boundary constraints, near geometric- and material discontinuities, such as ply dropoffs, and finally near structural/material defects such as in-plane and out-of-plane fiber misalignments. These multi-axial states of stress often involve combined transverse and shear loading, which can have a profound effect on the failure behavior of the material. Extensive research has been conducted on the general failure behavior and prediction of polymer matrix composites,1 and an abundance of different failure criteria of varying complexity and predictive capabilities have been proposed. Non-interactive and interactive criteria such as maximum stress, maximum strain2 and the Tsai-Wu failure criteria3 are typically used in industry. However, the first two do not take into account the effect of normal and shear stress interaction and the latter is not directly based on any physical mechanisms, despite performing well in many cases.1 More advanced failure theories, such as the LaRC4–8 and Puck9,10 criteria, introduce additional fitting parameters that need to be determined experimentally to better fit the test data. Furthermore, these criteria can be computationally expensive to use for large (real) scale composite structures. The Northwestern University (NU) failure theory proposed by Daniel et al.11,12 attempts to model the interlaminar/interfiber failure of composites, is relatively inexpensive computationally, and does not require additional parameters other than the conventional strengths and stiffnesses of the unidirectional material. The NU theory has been shown to perform very well for carbon fiber composites (CFRP) but has not yet been tested extensively on glass fiber reinforced composites (GFRP). Most failure theories for unidirectional composites are based on linear elastic behavior; however, some materials exhibit significant non-linear stress–strain response when subjected to combined loading. The polymeric matrix plays a bigger role in load carrying when uniaxial tensile/compressive loading is applied at an off-axis angle relative to the fiber direction. Thus, the non-linear material behavior of a composite laminate under combined loading is mainly attributed to the non-linear behavior of the polymer matrix. Lomov et al. have conducted extensive research on non-crimp fabric composites and have shown that the non-linear behavior can also be partly attributed to the initiation of micro damage in the matrix material.13–16 This was established using Acoustic Emission (AE) to monitor the damage progression in the specimens during testing. The results showed that, depending on the material system, the non-linear stress–strain response resulted in an increase of cumulative AE events, corresponding to damage initiation. For certain structures, such as wind turbine blades, which are subjected to combined extreme static loads and fatigue loading during their lifetime, in the latter case often in excess of 108 cycles, it is crucial to be able to predict the onset of damage. Moreover, from the point of view of a design engineer it is necessary to have an easily understandable failure criterion, which includes few easily measureable material parameters and is computationally efficient, while still yielding a good correlation between predictions and experimental results.

The objective of the present investigation is to determine if existing failure theories can predict the failure behavior of typical wind turbine blade laminate configurations under realistic loading conditions. Experimental results are given of extensive static tensile, compressive and in-plane shear tests on a glass fiber/epoxy composite at various orientations with the principal material directions. These results provide the parameters needed for input in classical failure theories and characterizes the material behavior under combined normal and shear loading. The experimental data are compared with the predictions of several classical failure theories and the newly proposed NU criterion for interfiber/interlaminar failure. The paper concludes with an assessment of the predictive capabilities of the considered failure theories for the wind turbine applications mentioned before.

sec.title: Material system and test specimens
sec.p:
The material investigated was a uni-directional E-glass/epoxy composite fabric. The dry fiber mat consists of 650 g/m2 fibers in the 0° direction and a 10 g/m2 stitch in the in-plane 90° direction. The stitch fibers primarily hold the 0° fiber bundles and have a negligible contribution to the stiffness and strength of the composite. Laminates of 2, 5 and 22 mm thickness were cast by stacking UD plies and infusing them with epoxy in a VARTM process. After infusion the laminates were allowed to cure at room temperature and were subsequently post cured in an oven. The fiber volume fraction of the finished laminates was measured to be approximately 58%. The material coordinate system used is shown in Figure 1. The “1-2 material plane” is the plane defined by the longitudinal (1) and transverse in-plane (2) axes and is also referred to as the interlaminar plane. The “1-3 material plane” is likewise defined by the longitudinal (1) and transverse through-thickness (3) axes and is also referred to as the interfiber plane. Figure 1.
Material coordinate system used.

The tensile specimens (see Figure 2) were cut from the 2 - and 5-mm-thick laminates in both rectangular and dog-bone shapes, and end tabs were bonded to the former according to the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) standard.17 Figure 2.
(a) Dog-bone specimen geometry for uniaxial and off-axis tensile tests in 1-2 material plane. (b) Rectangular specimen for tensile tests in the transverse 2-direction (the figures are not to scale).

The specimens for compression testing in the 1-2 plane were machined to a waisted-block geometry, see Figure 3, from the 22-mm plate with reduced cross-section, guided by the ASTM standard.18 Figure 3.
(a) Waisted block specimen for off-axis compression tests in the material 1-2 plane. (b) Geometry of test specimen, load direction indicated by arrow.

For compression tests in the 1-3 plane, rectangular specimens were machined from the 22-mm plate as described by Toftegaard and Goutianos19 and Daniel et al.,20 see Figure 4. Figure 4.
Rectangular specimens for uni-axial and off-axis compression tests in the 1-3 material plane.

Regular symmetric (V-notched) and asymmetric Iosipescu specimen geometries (see Figure 5), according to the ASTM standard21 and Kratmann et al.,22 respectively, were chosen for shear testing in both the 1-2 and 1-3 planes, respectively. It is common for the regular symmetric Iosipescu specimen to develop axial splits before failure.22 These axial splits cause significant redistribution of the stress and strain fields in the specimen gauge section, accompanied by non-uniform shear stress distribution. Kratmann and co-workers have shown that using the asymmetric specimen geometry it was possible to suppress the occurrence of axial splits, and thereby obtain experimental shear strength data with significantly less scatter.22 Figure 5.
Photographs of symmetric (top) and asymmetric (middle) Iosipescu specimens. Sketch of asymmetric Iosipescu geometry according to reference 22 shown at bottom.

The Iosipescu specimens were machined from the 2 -, 5 - and 22-mm-thick plates. The asymmetric specimens were machined from the 5-mm plate without further finishing, while the symmetric specimens were ground to a uniform thickness of 4 mm. There was no apparent difference between the failure mechanisms between specimens with and without tabs. The test matrix including specimen geometries and properties is presented in Table 1 with F denoting the material strength, and E and G the Young’s and shear moduli, respectively. The subscripts denote the orientation and sign of the strength, that is, tension (t) or compression (c). The superscript OA indicates off-axis testing. Table 1.
Test matrix with specimen geometry and dimensions
Test type Shape Dimensions (mm) Property
Tension Rectangular 175 × 25 × 4 F2t, E2.
Tension Dog bone 240 × 30 × 2 F2t, E2, FtOA
Compression Rectangular solid 6 × 6 × 20 & 20 × 20 × 40 E3, F3c, FcOA
Compression ‘Waisted block-like’ 90 × 30 × 22 F2c, FcOA
Shear Symmetric and asymmetric Iosipescu 75 × 20 × 4 & 75 × 20 × 5 G12, F6, G13, F5
Shear Asymmetric Iosipescu 75 × 20 × 2 G12, F6

The off-axis angles were chosen with a 15°. interval as this was assessed to give a reasonable indication of the general material behavior under different combinations of normal load and shear. The smaller dimensions of the rectangular coupons, compared to the compression specimens for testing in the 1-2 plane, were chosen as it is difficult to manufacture sufficiently thick material of uniform quality for testing in the 1-3 material plane. The shear tests on the Iosipescu specimens with a thickness of 2 mm were performed as part of a M.Sc. thesis23 which was limited to testing in the material 1–2 plane.

sec.title: Experimental methods
sec.p:
As mentioned in the introduction, there are two primary objectives for the material characterization. The first is to determine the material stiffness and strength properties needed as input for the failure theories. These properties were determined by means of longitudinal and transverse tensile and compressive tests as well as shear tests, see Table 1. The second objective was to determine the material behavior under combined normal and shear loading. This was achieved by testing off-axis specimens, as illustrated in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Illustration of an off-axis specimen under uniaxial compression.

Figure 6 shows a rectangular specimen with the fiber direction, 1-axis, at an angle α with the loading direction, x-axis. By varying α it is possible to obtain various combinations of the transverse normal (σ2 and σ3, eq. (1)), and the shear stresses, (τ6 and τ5, eq. (2)) as described below: (1)σ2,3=σx·cos(α)2 (2)τ6,5=-σx·sin(α)·cos(α)

sec.title: Shear tests
sec.p:
The shear tests were performed using a Iosipescu shear fixture21 (see Figure 7), under a constant cross-head speed of 2 mm/min. Strain gauges were used on all specimens, however, only one side of the asymmetric specimens was monitored. Digital Image Correlation (DIC) measurements (explained further in the DIC section) were performed on the Iosipescu specimens cut from the 2-mm-thick plate. Figure 7.
Schematic illustration of the asymmetric Iosipescu shear test fixture and specimen.

sec.title: Tensile tests
sec.p: Uniaxial tensile tests were performed on the rectangular and the dog-bone specimens cut at 90° with the longitudinal fiber direction. Off-axis tensile tests were performed on dog-bone specimens cut at 15°, 30°, 45°, 60° and 75° with the longitudinal fiber direction. Cross-head speeds of 1 and 2 mm/min were used for all tests. Strain gauges and DIC were used to measure the strain and deformation fields on the dog-bone specimens, see DIC section for more details.

sec.title: Compression tests
sec.p: Compression testing on the 6 × 6 × 20 mm and 20 × 20 × 40 mm specimens cut in the 1-3 plane was performed at angles of 30°, 45°, 60°, 75° and 90° with the fiber direction. The specimens were monitored with strain gauges and were tested at a constant cross-head speed of 0.2 mm/min up to failure. The partially waisted block specimens were cut at angles of 15°, 30°, 45°, 60°, 75° and 90° and loaded gradually to failure, while monitoring them with strain gauges and DIC. All tests were performed using parallel compression platens, thereby avoiding the influence of mechanical grips that can lead to crack initiation and premature specimen failure away from the gauge section. The specimens were relatively thick to minimize the tendency for buckling and bending.

sec.title: DIC
sec.p:
The DIC method enables the measurement of full field displacements on the surface of a test specimen by tracking a random speckle pattern and has been used extensively before on composite materials, see Kratmann et al.,22 Koerber et al.,24 and LeBlanc and Shukla.25 Sutton et al.,26 also investigated the applicability of different DIC measuring configurations on problems with significant out-of-plane deformation and rotation. The DIC measurements were performed using the commercial system ARAMIS 4M from GOM mbH.27 The system specifications and computational parameters are listed in Table 2. No smoothing operations were subsequently used to post process the calculated strain maps. The noise was evaluated from two consecutive images of an unloaded specimen; the results are listed in Table 2, where (t/c/s) indicates values for the tension/compression/shear specimens, respectively. The measured strain maps were used to calculate an average strain over the gauge section as shown in Figures 2, 3 and 7 on the specimen surface, and whenever a dual 2D DIC is used, to filter out out-of-plane bending effects. Table 2.
DIC system specifications and measurement parameters
System/software ARAMIS 4 M/v.6.2.0
Cameras 8-bit 2048 × 2048 pixels, CCD
Field of view 35 mm× 35 mm
Spatial resolution (t/c/s) 3.5/3.5/0.8 mm
Subset size (t/c/s) 25/20/25 pixels
Subset shift (t/c/s) 25/25/15 pixels
Strain computational field 7 × 7
Validity quote 55%
Noise (t/c/s) ±300 micro strain
DIC: Digital Image Correlation.

sec.title: Experimental results
sec.p: The following three sections contain a brief description of the experimental results with emphasis on the material properties needed for composite failure analysis, namely, stiffnesses and strengths. Whenever the same property was measured from different test specimens, the resulting mean value was used in the failure analysis. The off-axis test results are compared with the predictions of selected failure criteria in the Failure analysis section.

sec.title: Shear tests
sec.p:
The symmetric Iosipescu specimens of thickness 4 mm (see Table 1) produced average shear strengths, F6 and F5, of 80 MPa and 66 MPa, respectively (Table 3). However, several types of matrix shear damage, in the form of both axial splits and delaminations in the through thickness direction, were observed during the tests, see Figure 8, with the implication that the specimens were no longer loaded in pure shear. Axial splits are defined in the ASTM standard21 and the accompanying load drop is not considered to be an ultimate failure load. Figure 8.
Iosipescu specimens after testing. Left: asymmetric geometry, right: symmetric geometry. Note axial splits in the image on the right. Table 3.
Results from the Iosipescu tests
G12/G13 F6/F5
Specimen and material orientation Number of specimens Mean (GPa) Standard deviation (GPa) Mean (MPa) Standard deviation (MPa)
Symmetric, 4 mm, 1-2 material plane 7 4.76 0.22 80 5.13
Asymmetric, 5 mm, 1-2 material plane 4 4.82 0.26 72 1.2
Asymmetric, 2 mm, 1-2 material plane 5 4.0 0.2 – –
Symmetric, 4 mm, 1-3 material plane 5 4.89 0.17 66 1.47
Table 4.
Results from the transverse tensile tests (2-direction)
E2 F2t
Number of specimens Mean (GPa) Standard deviation (GPa) Mean (MPa) Standard deviation (MPa)
Tensile, rectangular 5 13.6 0.85 42 4.5

In an attempt to prevent axial splits, a number of asymmetric Iosipescu specimens that were cut in the material 1-2 plane were tested (thickness 2 mm, see Table 1). A finite element (FE) model of the Iosipescu specimen (Figure 9 top left) was developed using the built-in ANSYS 8-node quadratic PLANE82 element. Displacements were prescribed on the model and a mesh convergence check was run. The model showed good convergence at 98,000 degrees of freedom, and the results revealed that the stress/strain fields in the gauge section of the asymmetric Iosipescu specimen are non-uniform, as shown on the left side of Figure 9.22,23 Figure 9 (bottom right) shows the stress correction factor over the specimen gauge section, based on the normalized shear stress by the average (uniform) shear stress in the specimen gauge section. To compensate for the non-uniformity of the shear stress distribution in the gauge section, a shear stress correction factor can be calculated and applied to the measured strain field.22 In this case, a value of ∼1.2 was found for the correction factor based on the FE analysis. Figure 9. Left.
FE plot of shear stress normalized by the average (uniform) gauge section shear stress. Right top: FE mesh of Iosipescu specimen. Right bottom: Shear stress correction factor along the gauge section.23 FE: finite element.

The asymmetric Iosipescu tests with specimen thickness 4 mm yielded an average shear strength F6 of 72 MPa; the results are summarized in Table 3. However, there was still visual evidence of massive delaminations, as described earlier (Figure 8 left), before the failure load was reached. Some specimens still showed axial splits and crushing of the contact surfaces, although the DIC measurements revealed that these effects had no influence on the modulus calculations, as they typically occurred after the onset of the non-linear stress–strain response. This is indicated in Figure 10 (right), which shows the typical stress–strain response of a specimen at a shear load of 917 N, which furthermore becomes noticeably non-linear above 0.5% strain. Figure 10.
Strain measurement in Iosipescu specimens. Left: DIC image of shear strain (ε12) field before axial split initiation (at 917 N load), right: typical stress–strain (γ12) response. DIC: Digital Image Correlation. Table 5.
Off-axis tensile strengths in 1-2 material plane
Off-axis angle 15° 30° 45° 60° 75°
Mean tensile strength (MPa) 109 53 47 36 32

A DIC shear strain map of an asymmetric Iosipescu specimen is shown in Figure 10 (left). The inhomogeneous shear strain field is clearly seen. The horizontally aligned strain concentrations in the specimen gauge zone are caused by the relatively large size of the 0° fiber bundles, which cause a significant increase in stiffness when stacked together for the 2-mm-thick specimen.

The measurements on the Iosipescu specimens yielded shear modulus G12 values of 4.76 GPa and 4.82 GPa for the symmetric and asymmetric specimens, respectively. DIC measurements on the 2-mm-thick specimens yielded a shear modulus G12 of 4 GPa. The shear modulus G13 was measured on symmetric Iosipescu specimens as 4.89 GPa. The results from the Iosipescu tests are summarized in Table 3.

sec.title: Uniaxial tests along principal directions
sec.p:
The 90° (transverse to the fiber direction) tension specimens failed at approximately 0.33% strain. Some specimens failed in the grip area, but this did not affect the measured strength, compared to the specimens that failed in the gauge section. A failed specimen can be seen in Figure 11. Figure 11.
Typical transverse tensile test specimen after failure.

The stress–strain curves for all tests were nearly linear up to failure. The mean tensile strength, F2t, was measured to be 42 MPa. The average Young’s modulus, E2, was measured as 13.6 GPa. These results are summarized in Table 4.

sec.title: Off-axis tests
sec.p:
All off-axis tension specimens failed along the fiber direction. Most specimens failed in the gauge zone. The 15° off-axis specimens had a tendency to fail near the grips, and the fractures spanned both the gauge and transition zone, as shown in Figure 12. Figure 12.
Off-axis tension specimens after failure. From top to bottom, 75°, 60°, 45°, 30° and 15° off-axis orientations (with respect to the fiber direction).

The stress–strain curves for the off-axis tension tests show mild non-linear behavior up to failure for the specimens with load orientations in the range of 15°–75° relative to the fiber direction, as shown in Figure 13. Figure 13.
Typical stress–strain response for the off-axis tensile tests.

Figure 14 shows a typical DIC strain map of a 30° off-axis specimen, the fiber orientation is clearly seen at a load level of 2.7 kN. The strain concentration near the edge, shown on the left hand side of Figure 14, may be caused by premature failure due to edge-effects. Figure 14.
Longitudinal strain map for a 30° off-axis tensile specimen (load level 2.7 kN).
The tensile strength decreases with increasing off-axis angle, most significantly between the 15°, 30° and 45° specimens, see Table 5.

sec.title: Uniaxial tests along principal directions
sec.p:
The 90° (transverse to the fiber direction) partially waisted compression specimens that were cut along the 2-direction failed at an average compressive stress of 130 MPa (see Table 6). The rectangular specimens cut in the 3-direction reached average compression strengths, F3c, of 120 MPa and 123 MPa, for the 6 × 6 × 20 mm and 20 × 20 × 40 mm specimens, respectively (Tables 7 and 8). Both specimen types showed matrix failure patterns as seen in Figure 15. Figure 15.
Uniaxial transverse compression specimens after failure (20 × 20 × 40 mm). Table 6.
Results from the waisted-block specimen compression tests for the material 2-direction
F2c
Number of specimens Mean (MPa) Standard deviation (MPa)
Compression, waisted-block, 90 × 30 × 22 3 130 2.5
Table 7.
Results from the rectangular specimen compression tests in the material 3-direction
E3 F3c
Number of specimens Mean (GPa) Standard deviation (GPa) Mean (MPa) Standard deviation (MPa)
Compression, 6 × 6 × 20 3 12.7 0.6 120 2.1
Table 8.
Results from the rectangular specimen compression tests in the material 3-direction
E3 F3c
Number of specimens Mean (GPa) Standard deviation (GPa) Mean (MPa) Standard deviation (MPa)
Compression, 20 × 20 × 40 5 12.7 0.3 123 1
The fracture plan orientation was measured between 38° and 40°. For both specimen types, the average Young’s modulus, E3, was measured as 12.7 GPa, results are summarized in Tables 7 and 8.

The stress–strain curves for all tests become noticeably non-linear above 1% strain, as shown in Figure 16 for test specimens in the 3-direction. Figure 16.
Typical stress–strain response in transverse compression in the 3-direction.

sec.title: Off-axis tests
sec.p:
All off-axis test specimens, both in the 1-2 and 1-3 material coordinate planes, with the exception of the 15° specimens, showed pronounced non-linear stress strain behavior over 0.5% strain, as illustrated in Figure 17. Figure 17.
Typical stress–strain curves of off-axis compression specimens. Left: 1-3 material plane. Right: 1-2 material plane.

As with the off-axis tensile tests, the compression strength decreases as the off-axis angle is increased, for the 1-2 plane specimens. This is especially pronounced between the 15° and 30° off-axis angles, as seen in Table 9. The strengths in the 1-3 plane on the other hand show a slight tendency to increase with increasing off-axis angles between 30° and 90°, see Table 10. Most specimens failed in the gauge or transition zone, as seen in Figures 18 and 19. The 15° specimens failed mostly by kink-band formation, as shown in Figure 20. Some specimens showed fractures that spanned both the gauge, transition and load introduction zones, and it was not possible to identify the exact location of failure initiation with the measurement methods used. Figure 18.
Off-axis compression specimens (in 1-2 plane) after failure. From left to right, 75°, 60°, 45°, 30° and 15° off-axis angles (with respect to the fiber direction). Figure 19.
Off-axis compression specimens (in 1-3 plane) after failure. From left to right, 75°, 60°, 45°, 30° and 15° off-axis angles (with respect to the fiber direction). Figure 20.
Kink band failure mechanism in 15° off-axis compression specimens. Table 9.
Off-axis compressive strengths in 1-2 material plane
Off-axis angle 15° 30° 45° 60° 75°
Mean off-axis compressive strength (MPa) 239 157 142 139 131
Table 10.
Off-axis compressive strengths in 1-3 material plane
Off-axis angle 30° 45° 60° 75°
Mean off-axis compressive strength (MPa) 112 113 117 125

Figure 21 shows a typical DIC strain map for a 60° off-axis compression specimen in the 1-2 material plane (load level −36 kN). As in Figure 14, the fiber orientation can be clearly identified. Figure 21.
DIC longitudinal strain map for a 60° off-axis compression specimen, load is −36 kN. DIC: Digital Image Correlation.

sec.title: Determination of failure initiation strength
sec.p: In an attempt to provide a more conservative shear strength estimate, that is, a ‘shear strength’ that can be used for design purposes to avoid matrix shear damage and plasticity, it is proposed to use a ‘failure onset strength’ or ‘failure initiation strength’ referring to the work of Lomov and co-workers.13–16 The stress–strain curves observed generally display various degrees of progressing non-linearity, where the non-linear material behavior is caused by progressive damage accumulation (matrix cracking, interface failure and fiber breakage), which leads to a gradual change (decrease) of the stiffness.

The ‘failure initiation strength’ is defined by the point on the stress–strain curve at which the relative change of the material stiffness is either largest or starts to increase significantly, which must be evaluated for each test type and depends mostly on how abruptly the material starts to exhibit non-linear response. In practice this is computed by dividing the stress–strain curve into a number of smaller segments. The slope of one segment is calculated by approximating the curve by a sequentially linear fit and compared to the slope of the preceding segment as illustrated in Figure 22. Figure 22.
Graphical illustration of the proposed method to define ‘failure initiation strength’ (or point) by the slope of the stress–strain curve.

The size of the segments depends on the stiffness/material of the specimen, loading speed and measuring frequency, the noise on the measurement signal and so on. If the stiffness/modulus of the tested specimen is very high, the segments should be small enough to accurately represent the stress–strain response. If the measurement frequency has been too low, and there are few data points available, or the signal is noisy, it may be necessary to perform smoothing/interpolation operations on the measured data.

The slope of each segment is compared to the slope of the preceding segment by computing the percentage change. The point of failure initiation is defined as when this percentage change begins to increase significantly over the preceding values, which again depends on the size of the segments. For the material and measurement techniques presently used, a segment size between 0.05% and 0.1% strain was found to represent the data adequately, and a stiffness change (decrease) of 50% was used to define the ‘failure initiation point/strength.’
This ‘failure initiation strength’ can be regarded similarly as the yield strength of ductile materials, typically defined by the 0.2% offset point, which is based on empirical considerations.

It is proposed to use this method for any kind of loading that produces a combined shear/normal stress state and whenever a more conservative strength estimation is required, assuming that the non-linear material behavior is caused by progressive damage accumulation as described above. (The method was used on the Iosipescu shear tests, as well as the off-axis compression tests in the Failure analysis section.)

sec.title: Failure analysis
sec.p: Several failure criteria were evaluated based on the obtained experimental results: the maximum stress criterion,2 the fully interactive Tsai-Wu criterion3 and the failure mode-based NU criterion.11,12 According to the maximum stress theory, failure in the material 1-2 plane occurs when one of the following sub criteria are met:2 (3)σ2=F2t, if σ2>0 or σ2=F2c, if σ2<0 (4)|τ6|=F6

The Tsai-Wu failure criterion in the material 1-2 plane is given by:3 (5)f1σ1+f2σ2+f6σ6+f11σ12+f22σ22+f66σ62+2f12σ1σ2=1 where f1=1F1t-1F1c, f11=-1F1tF1c, f2=1F2t-1F2c,f22=-1F2tF2c, f66=1F62 and f12≅-12f11f22

The NU interfiber/interlaminar failure theory, proposed by Daniel et al.,11 is based on the assumption that the failure of composite materials is governed by the limiting microscopic strain in the interfiber/interlaminar region of the lamina. A compression dominated failure is thus governed by the microscopic shear strain (Figure 23), a shear dominated failure is governed by the tensile strain (Figure 24), and a failure by combined tension and shear is dominated by tensile strains (Figure 25). Figure 23.
Illustration of the limiting microscopic shear strain in the interlaminar region for a compression dominated failure.11 Figure 24.
Illustration of the limiting microscopic tensile strain in the interlaminar region for a shear dominated failure.11 Figure 25.
Illustration of the limiting microscopic tensile strain in the interlaminar region for a tension dominated failure.11

The NU theory consists of separate subcriteria for tension and compression failure, and furthermore separates the latter into compression and shear dominated failures, respectively. These three subcriteria are thus mostly applicable to anisotropic materials where the interlaminar failure can be distinguished into three separate and non/weakly interacting failure modes. The three subcriteria are given by the following equations in the 1-2 material plane:11
NUa/Compression dominated failure, see also Figure 23: (6)(σ2F2c)2+(τ6F2c)2·(E2G12)2=1
NUb/Shear dominated failure, see also Figure 24: (7)(τ6F6)2+2·σ2F6·G12E2=1
NUc/Tension dominated failure, see also Figure 25: (8)σ2F2t+(τ6F2t)2·(E22·G12)2=1

The three criteria given by equations (3) to (8) are equally applicable to the 1-3 plane by interchanging subscripts 2 and 6 with 3 and 5, respectively. Equations (3) to (8) are used to create failure envelopes in the 1-2 and 1-3 planes, however, only for combined compression and shear in the 1-3 plane, due to the lack of experimental data. The material data used for input to the failure analysis are gathered from Tables 3 to 8 and summarized in Table 11, except the failure initiation shear strengths F6 and F5, which were established by the method described in the Determination of failure initiation strength section, as the original values were deemed not representative of the material strength. Table 11.
Material properties used for failure predictions
Property E2 (GPa) G12 (GPa) E3 (GPa) G13 (GPa) F2t (MPa) F2c (MPa) F6 (MPa) F3c (MPa) F5 (MPa)
Value 13.6 4.5 12.7 4.89 42 130 34 a 122 33 a
a
‘Failure initiation strength’ as proposed in the Determination of failure initiation strength section.

The results from the off-axis tests (Tables 5, 9 and 10) are plotted to evaluate the three different failure criteria in Figure 26 along with the failure initiation strengths. The failure initiation strengths (listed in Tables 12 and 13) were calculated with the method to define failure initiation, described in the Determination of failure initiation strength section, from the off-axis ultimate strengths given in Tables 9 and 10. Figure 26.
Comparison between experimental results and theoretical predictions in the 1-2 (left) and 1-3 (right) material planes, respectively, using the ‘failure initiation strength’ definition. Table 12.
Off-axis failure initiation compressive strengths in 1-2 material plane
Off-axis angle 15° 30° 45° 60° 75°
Mean off-axis failure initiation strength (MPa) 32 36 47 53 109
Table 13.
Off-axis failure initiation compressive strengths in 1-3 material plane
Off-axis angle 30° 45° 60° 75°
Mean off-axis failure initiation strength (MPa) 94 77 98 105

As seen from Figure 26, there does not appear to be a significant difference between the predictions of the NU and Tsai-Wu criteria in either the 1-2 or the 1-3 planes for the tested GFRP material. All failure theories also appear to be quite conservative compared to the experimentally determined ultimate failures. It should be noted that the NU failure curve between tension and shear dominated failures in the 1-2 plane (Figure 26 left) is not continuous, which indicates a slight mismatch in the experimentally determined constitutive data, as the NU theory assumes a certain relation between the stiffness and strength of a material. However, the theoretical predictions provide a much better fit to the failure initiation data, and as the method proposed in the Determination of failure initiation strength section is aimed at identifying the initiation of micro damage, again referring to the work of Lomov and co-workers,13–16 it thus appears that by analyzing the stress/strain response of a material, it is possible to use existing failure criteria to determine the applied load at which the failure of the investigated materials initiates. It may in fact be considered unrealistic to predict the ultimate failure of some composite materials by conventional failure theories, without including the non-linear material behavior. However, adding this feature to an already advanced failure criterion could easily result in the criterion becoming impractical for use in a design process due to the extensive computational efforts required. While it would still be required to employ other tools, for example, cohesive zone modeling or other strain energy release rate-based approaches, to predict the ultimate failure, the proposed method provides a tool to design for failure initiation. This in turn may also be more desirable, for example, in the case of fatigue loaded structures.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Classical lamination theory assumes the material properties in the two transverse directions to be identical for a unidirectional lamina. However, it was found that the mechanical properties in the 2-direction are slightly higher than in the 3-direction for the current glass/epoxy composite material. This can possibly be explained by the small amount of stitching in the 2-direction and the fact that the individual fiber bundles are wider than they are thick, both due to the manufacturing process and the design of the UD mat. This can be seen clearly in Figure 27. Figure 27.
The unidirectional GFRP seen along the fiber longitudinal direction. GFRP: glass fiber reinforced composites.

The measured strain maps of the shear, tensile and compression tests (Figures 10, 14 and 21) clearly show that the present material system, in contradiction to classical lamination theory, does not behave as a homogenous material/continuum at this level of resolution. Figure 8 shows clear signs of delamination/fiber bundle separation which may be considered more of a structural failure than material. This can complicate the process of determining the material parameters, as these can vary significantly, depending on the location and thus the measured strain in the specimen. While these in-homogeneities are insignificant on the scale of a large composite structure, they should be kept in mind when determining the size of the measuring area one uses for the determination of constitutive and strength parameters.

The use of the asymmetric Iosipescu test specimen should not give rise to differences in the measured shear stiffnesses. However, this was observed for the Iosipescu tests in the 1-2 plane. One difference between the two Iosipescu test series was that the asymmetric specimens had not been milled to an exact thickness, and as a result strain gauges were only applied on a single side. The strain readings from opposing gauges on the symmetric specimens revealed some difference, indicating specimen twisting, even with the use of tabs. It is therefore advised to apply strain gauges on both specimen sides for Iosipescu tests to filter out the effects of specimen twisting. It could also be desirable to use a fixture specifically designed for composites, as described by, for example, Pierron.28

The off-axis compression tests generally resulted in slightly higher strengths for the waisted block specimens in the 1-2 material plane than the rectangular block specimens cut in the 1-3 material plane. A possible explanation for this can be the chosen specimen geometry. While the chosen aspect ratio of the rectangular specimens should help reduce the influence of end effects, it cannot be ruled out to have had some impact on the strength. The same arguments can be applied regarding the edge effects of the waisted block and dog-bone specimens. However, both specimen types gave good repeatability of results in general, so the difference might also be attributed to the slight difference in base material properties, as discussed in the beginning of this section.

The proposed method of defining the point of damage initiation (referred to as the ‘failure initiation strength’) by analyzing the slope of the stress–strain curve, is a straight-forward approach that can be used on the results from standardized material tests. The presented work suggests some merit to the method, however the failure initiation strength obtained could be further validated by ‘monotonic loading’ tests in which specimens are loaded and unloaded to the failure initiation strength a number of times to determine if there is any permanent strain. A few initial tests were performed on the 6 × 6 × 20 mm rectangular solid specimens and a permanent strain was indeed identified. Future work should include more testing to further validate the proposed method. The method can also be sensitive to noisy stress–strain data, which can make it necessary to perform smoothing operations on the raw data. In some cases it can also be difficult to evaluate the results of the method and that is why sound skepticism and engineering judgment should always be employed when interpreting the model predictions.

The NU interlaminar/interfiber failure theory does by definition only apply to matrix dominated failures and does not distinguish between matrix and interfacial failures. A failure theory based on micromechanics would probably be needed in order to obtain a more detailed description of the failure process and the constituent interaction. However, this could easily defy the important objective of having a simple to use and computationally in-expensive failure criterion. The NU theory meets these requirements while being founded on physical considerations and providing good results.

sec.title: Summary and conclusions
sec.p: A unidirectional glass/epoxy composite material was characterized in both the 1-2 and 1-3 material planes, subjected to uniaxial and combined compression and shear loading for both material planes, as well as combined tension and shear loading for the 1-2 plane. The failure modes were analyzed and it was observed that all specimens failed by interlaminar/interfiber failure, except the 15° off-axis compression specimens in the 1-2 material plane, which failed by microbuckling and kink-band formation. The recorded stress–strain curves were used to define a point of failure initiation (failure initiation strength). This was done by identifying the point on the stress–strain curves at which the slope changes significantly or has a maximum value. The experimental results were used to evaluate three failure theories, of which the NU and Tsai-Wu criteria gave comparable results. The proposed method of analyzing the stress–strain response made it possible to use the existing failure theories to predict the point of damage initiation (or failure initiation strength) with reasonable accuracy.

ack.p: The work presented was conducted as part of an Industrial Ph.D. project carried out in collaboration between Siemens Wind Power A/S, Denmark, and the Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Aalborg University, Denmark. Some of the experimental work was done by M.Sc. students Brian Damgaard and Kaspar Tall as part of their Master thesis at Aalborg University. The authors are grateful for their contributions.

sec.p: None declared.
